step.context: \text{If two lines with slopes }m_1\text{ and }m_2 \\ \text{respectively are parallel, then }\ldots
\text{Are the analysis and conclusion below correct?}
step.tex: \text{Slope at a point (x,y)} = \frac{dy}{dx}. \\ \begin{align} \therefore\text{ slope }&= \dfrac{d}{dx}(7x^3 + 11) = 21x^2 \end{align} \\ \text{But as }\left[\dfrac{dy}{dx}\right]_{x=-2} = \left[\dfrac{dy}{dx}\right]_{x=2}, \text{the two tangents} \\ \text{have equal slopes }\implies\text{ they are parallel.}
step.reason: y = c\cdot x^2 \text{ has the same value for }x = \pm a. \text{That}\\ \text{is why, }\dfrac{dy}{dx}\text{ = tangent's slope, is same at }x=\pm 2.

step.context: \textbf{Bonus Question: }\text{Would the tangents at } \\ x=\pm 5\text{ also be parallel?}
step.reason: \text{We established in Step 2 that }\frac{dy}{dx}\text{ is the same} \\ \text{for }x = \pm a.\text{Hence, it must also be so for }x=\pm 5.\\ \text{Or, for that matter, any }x= \pm a.
